tuv.seg: Some types of evidence are admissible but are "suspect"
Tá cineálacha fianaise ann atá ceadaithe ach atá "amhrastúil"
This means that they often turn out to be untrue or incorrect
Fianaise í seo a bhíonn bréagach nó mícheart go minic sa deireadh
To protect the accused against being convicted on the basis of suspect evidence, safeguards have been put in place
Ar mhaithe leis an gcúisí a chosaint ó bheith ciontaithe bunaithe ar fhianaise amhrastúil tá cosaintí curtha i bhfeidhm
The most important safeguard against suspect evidence is the "corroboration warning"
Is é an "rabhadh comhthacaíochta" an chosaint is tábhachtaí a bhfuil ann i gcoinne fianaise atá amhrastúil
The corroboration warning is given at the end of the trial by the judge to the jury
Tugann an breitheamh rabhadh comhthacaíochta don ghiúiré ag deireadh na trialach
The warning points out to the jury that it is dangerous to convict the accused on the basis of the suspect evidence without any corroborative evidence
Cuireann an rabhadh seo ar a súile don ghiúiré go bhfuil sé contúirteach an cúisí a chiontú bunaithe ar fhianaise amhrastúil gan aon fhianaise chomhthacaíochta a bheith ar fáil
However, if the jury is satisfied beyond all reasonable doubt that the accused is guilty, then it can go on and convict even without corroborative evidence
Ach, má tá an giúiré sásta gan amhras réasúnta go bhfuil an cúisí ciontach, is féidir dul ar aghaidh agus é/í a chiontú gan aon fhianaise chomhthacaíochta
Corroborative evidence is additional evidence
Fianaise bhreise í fianaise chomhthacaíochta
It is evidence in a case which:
Is fianaise i gcás í a:
• Implicates the accused in the crime - it must tend to show that the accused was guilty of the offence charged
• luann an cúisí leis an gcoir - ní mór go mbeadh an cuma ón bhfianaise go bhfuil an cúisí ciontach as an gcoir atá curtha ina leith
• Is admissible and credible
• atá ceadaithe agus inchreidthe
• Is independent - it comes from a source other than the witness whose evidence needs corroboration
• atá neamhspleách - tagann sé ó fhoinse eile seachas ó fhinné a dteastaíonn comhthacaíocht óna c(h)uid fianaise
An accomplice is a person who was also involved in the alleged crime
Comhchoirí é/í duine a raibh baint aige/aici leis an gcoir atá curtha i leith cúisí
If an accomplice is giving evidence against the accused, the court will treat it as "suspect evidence"
Má bhíonn comhchoirí ag tabhairt fianaise i gcoinne an chúisí, breathnóidh an chúirt ar an bhfianaise mar "fhianaise amhrastúil"
This is because an accomplice may have a lot to gain by lying to pin the blame on the accused
Tá seo amhlaidh mar d'fhéadfadh go leor a bheith le fáil ag comhchoirí as iarracht a dhéanamh an milleán ar fad a chur ar an gcúisí

To protect the accused against being unfairly convicted on the basis of accomplice evidence alone, the judge, at the end of the trial, will sum up the case and must give a corroboration warning to the jury

Ar mhaithe leis an gcúisí a chosaint as a bheith ciontaithe ar fhianaise chomhchoirí amháin, ag deireadh na trialach, déanfaidh an breitheamh achoimre den chás don ghiúiré agus ní mór dó/dí rabhadh chomhthacaíochta a thabhairt don ghiúiré
A confession is a voluntary statement made by the accused implicating him/her in the alleged offence
Ráiteas deonach í admháil a dhéanann an cúisí agus a luann é/í féin leis an gcoir
Confession evidence is considered to be "suspect evidence" and since 1993, the judge must give a corroboration warning to the jury
Breathnaítear ar fhianaise admhála mar "fhianaise amhrastúil" agus ó 1993, ní mór don bhreitheamh rabhadh comhthacaíochta a thabhairt don ghiúiré
Evidence given by the alleged victim of a sexual offence
Fianaise tugtha ag duine a éilíonn gur fhulaing sé/sí coir ghnéis
Traditionally, the evidence of an alleged victim of a sexual offence was treated as "suspect" and the judge in such a case was obliged to give a corroboration warning to the jury

Go traidisiúnta, bhreathnaigh na cúirteanna ar fhianaise a thug duine a dúirt gur d'fhulaing sé/sí coir ghnéis mar fhianaise "amhrastúil" agus b'éigean don bhreitheamh i gcás mar sin rabhadh comhthacaíochta a thabhairt don ghiúiré
However, since 1990, the corroboration warning is no longer automatic and it is up to the judge to decide whether the warning is necessary in the particular case
Ach ó 1990, ní gá an rabhadh comhthacaíochta a thabhairt agus tá sé suas don bhreitheamh cinneadh a dhéanamh an bhfuil gá leis an rabhadh comhthacaíochta ag brath ar an gcás
Traditionally, children's evidence was treated as "suspect" and the judge in such a case was obliged to give a corroboration warning to the jury
Go traidisiúnta, bhreathnaigh na cúirteanna ar fhianaise a thug páistí mar fhianaise "amhrastúil" agus b'éigean don bhreitheamh i gcás mar sin rabhadh comhthacaíochta a thabhairt don ghiúiré
However, since 1992, the corroboration warning is no longer automatic and it is up to the judge to decide whether the warning is necessary in the particular case
Ach ó 1992, ní gá an rabhadh comhthacaíochta a thabhairt agus tá sé suas don bhreitheamh cinneadh a dhéanamh an bhfuil gá leis an rabhadh comhthacaíochta ag brath ar an gcás
For more detailed information you should seek legal advice
Ba chóir duit comhairle dlí a lorg chun faisnéis mionsonraithe a fháil
